Jesse James.Action: Stands quietly near Web Mimms, showing protective presence to a terrified younger companion.
Appears angry and tense in a dangerous situation, but remains near allies.
Drives rifle butt into soldier's nose, bashes another soldier's jaw, shoots multiple soldiers in close combat.
Stops short when confronting a young soldier, recognizes his youth, and waves him off without shooting.
Moves skillfully and confidently in the chaos of battle, disarming and incapacitating multiple enemies with improvised use of their weapons.
Successfully uses quick thinking to avoid fatal injury by relying on his ammo belts to stop a bayonet.
Maintains control and composure when faced with a young enemy combatant, choosing to spare him rather than escalate the violence.
Waves off a boy with guns instead of engaging him warmly.
Shares lighthearted banter and teasing with Frank.
Receives a bear hug from Cole and responds without rejecting, indicating closeness.
Declines to ride with Cole and opts to walk, a neutral personal choice showing no warmth nor coldness.
Shows awareness of dangerous situation in occupied territory and cautions Cole to avoid provoking soldiers.
Displays humor and camaraderie with his gang during tough times, maintaining morale.
Shows a strong commitment to protect his farm and family, expressing readiness to go to war with the railroad to keep his land.
Dismisses Frank's suggestion of fabricating a story to avoid danger, doubting its effectiveness.
Does not fully grasp the political and legal complexities of the threat posed by the railroad and the military tribunals.
Successfully drives a post straight into a hole while working with Cole, showing practical skill.
Engages in witty verbal banter with Cole and Frank, demonstrating quick thinking and social confidence.
Shows some momentary concession (agreeing Sadie was a woman) to keep peace in conversation, indicating social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Relaxes and thanks Cole for help, showing leadership and gratitude.
Dismisses missing the war in a thoughtful way, acknowledging complexity rather than glorifying violence.
Cole declares they were great at killing; Jesse acknowledges being terrifying with guns confidently.
Jesse responds to Parker's formal introduction with sarcastic wit, showing quick thinking and confidence.
Sighs and calmly asks how many detectives Cole killed after Bob's report of violence.
Tells the crowd to disperse and swear they know nothing to prevent any involvement or risk, demonstrating strategic thinking and control.
Calms Doc Mimms and assures that no more hangings will occur, showing confidence and leadership.
Refuses Jim Younger's involvement citing his youth and inexperience, showing judgment and ability to make difficult decisions.
Responds to Zee's questioning by telling him to go home, indicating possible dismissal of useful information gathering.
Plans and signals willingness to take on overwhelming odds (seven of them against a Union regiment and Pinkerton detectives) in broad daylight on Main Street, smiles confidently.
Remains hidden and protected while seriously wounded, allowing Zee to successfully deceive the Union officer.
Appears groggy and unconscious, unable to take active measures to protect himself at a critical moment.
Hops easily into the carriage and manages social interaction despite awkwardness.
Speaks awkwardly and hesitantly when trying to ask Doc Mimms for permission.
Glares slowly at Frank in response to teasing, showing controlled but confident nonverbal communication.
Receives enthusiastic applause and respect from people at the party, indicating social competence and reputation.
Smoothly swings Zee into a group of dancers and joins the Two-Step, showing confidence and social skill.
Carries a lantern and leads Zee up the hill to a quiet spot with a beautiful view, showing thoughtful planning and awareness.
Engages in light-hearted, clever banter about being a river pirate and future aspirations, demonstrating wit and imaginative thinking.
Openly admits to having outgrown childish ambitions, showing self-awareness and maturity.
Teases Zee playfully about her buck teeth in a friendly manner.
Quotes Shakespeare dreamily and sincerely to Zee, showing tenderness.
Admits openly he has been planning to kiss Zee for a long time, showing sincerity and affection.
Kisses Zee with mutual affection and intimacy.
Immediately responds to crisis with urgency and helps form a response after barn is set on fire.
Cries openly holding his severely burned mother, expresses deep anguish and pain at her death.
Urgently tries to save his mother, risking his own safety as his coat catches fire.
Ignores practical warnings (Frank stamping out his coat) in order to stay close to his mother.
Expresses intense rage and pain with a prolonged howl after his mother's death.
Rejects Frank’s suggestion to move on and rebuild, showing stubbornness and refusal to accept change.
Races toward burning house despite danger, coat catches fire, but continues trying to get close to his mother.
Despite panic and grief, attempts to get mother to Doc Mimms and focus on her care.
Shows inability to control emotions, openly crying and howling in rage and pain in front of others.
Rejects practical suggestion to move on and rebuild after loss, indicating stubbornness but perhaps poor long-term planning.
Confidently declares his intent to bring enemies to ashes and be feared.
Leads a coordinated bank robbery with disguises and armed intimidation.
Responds calmly and efficiently when confronted by the bank manager, drawing weapons to assert control.
Fails to address Zee's concerns about justice and consequences, showing emotional detachment.
Has a staredown with the bank manager, not showing kindness or friendliness.
Half covers his eyes and turns his head when a shot is about to be fired, demonstrating some sensitivity.
Calmly stops the gang from shooting the sheriff, confidently negotiates to avoid conflict.
Successfully robs the bank with his gang, demonstrating effective leadership and planning.
Remains stoic, giving nothing away when asked to respond to a suggestion.
Grins and slaps Cole on the back after joking about shooting Pinkerton detectives.
Nods without giving anything up when asked about a suggestion, showing controlled and confident demeanor.
Proposes targeting a construction depot guarded by Pinkerton detectives, showing strategic thinking about bigger rewards.
Expresses eagerness to shoot Pinkerton detectives more as bravado than strategic planning.
Drops a handful of twenty dollar gold pieces into the church collection plate.
Signs autographs for a group of boys swarming around him.
Sighs and acknowledges Bob's feelings about the 'Wanted!' posters, showing awareness of brother's insecurity.
Expresses love and affection toward his brother Frank during a tense moment.
Displays aggression by hurling a whisky bottle against the wall in anger.
Shows concern for Jim Younger by warning him he is too young to be drinking whisky.
Jesse forces the railroad company to choose a costlier detour to avoid him, effectively winning a strategic standoff.
Plans and times his robberies carefully, always striking before returning to Liberty, Missouri—shows strategic planning and consistent pattern.
Despite Pinkerton's prediction and tracking efforts, Jesse continues to operate with confidence, indicating he understands his enemies and the risks well.
Expresses skepticism about the plan despite others' enthusiasm, indicating cautiousness and concern for the group's safety.
Allows Cole to lead the bank robbery plan, deferring authority to cousin despite personal reservations.
Crosses to window and sags against it, showing exhaustion and possible emotional vulnerability amidst the group's tension.
Shoves Cole and Frank down to protect them from gunfire.
Aggressively fights and kills attackers without hesitation.
Opens up honestly about his identity to ensure the marriage is legal, showing confidence and forward planning.
Successfully negotiates with the pastor, securing a discreet arrangement, paying for repairs, and partaking in communion, displaying social tact and strategic patience.
Absence from the bank robbery led by his associates results in disappointment and perhaps loss of respect from the gang members.
Pulls a chuckling Zee up out of the sand and splashes around playfully with her, ending in a kiss and embrace.
Instructs Zee not to look at the approaching enemy to deny reality and protect her emotionally.
Expresses longing at the open ocean before surrendering peacefully to Pinkerton detectives.
Confidently confronts Parker, remembers him and accuses him of killing his mother, showing sharp memory and boldness.
Winks and asserts he made Rains think twice about burning homes, indicating psychological insight and ability to intimidate.
Is caught by surprise and sucker punched by Parker, showing a momentary lack of vigilance or underestimation of enemies.
Threatens Rains with a visit, showing determination and steel in his voice.
Maintains composure despite being shackled and surrounded by armed detectives.
Taunts and insults the Burly Detective with mocking nicknames and crude jokes.
Grins and speaks defiantly even after being backhanded and injured.
Maintains a low, terrifying voice to intimidate while staring down a gun aimed at his face.
Uses humor to provoke and antagonize his captors despite the danger.
Fights aggressively and violently to escape custody, shooting Pinkertons without hesitation.
Grabs Web to his chest and shields the boy with his own body during heavy gunfire.
Tries to stop Web's bleeding with his bare hands after being wounded.
Slaps Cole's shoulder, shares a smile, and takes a leadership role by planning a distraction to help comrades under fire.
Charges at full gallop, risking personal safety to create a distraction during the battle, showing commitment to his group.
Leaps dramatically over a barrier to lead a charge, firing at enemy troops and rallying his men.
Quickly distracts the Missouri Rangers, accomplishing the task before Frank finishes assessing the situation.
Engages in confident banter with Frank showing decisiveness and swift action.
Chooses to walk instead of riding with the others, possibly indicating self-awareness or strategic patience.
Shows clear-headedness and determination to return home and protect his farm, expressing commitment to his family and homeland.
Displays toughness and readiness to kill anyone who threatens their homes, expressing a harsh, unforgiving stance.
Jesse jokes about shooting a horse 'just on principle' after long time in saddle.
Jesse warmly calls the town 'Home, boys. Back to our farms.' encouraging camaraderie.
Warns Cole to keep his hand off his hip to avoid unnecessary fights, showing protective and prudent behavior.
Stops Cole from cutting down bodies immediately, suggesting strategic caution not to alert the Union Soldiers.
Expresses immediate fondness and enthusiasm towards Zerelda Mimms, hugs warmly.
Grabs Cole's arm and stops him from cutting down the bodies to avoid being seen by Union soldiers; plans for a tactical advantage if violence occurs
Immediately recognizes potential danger of being observed by enemies; acts with calculated caution
Shows emotional distraction when noticing Zerelda Mimms, potentially indicating vulnerability
Is obviously, immediately smitten with Zee and tries to compliment her despite awkwardness.
Rushing to help Doc Mimms after he staggers and slumps down.
Sits with the family, recounts Web's brave actions to comfort and reassure them.
Acknowledges and praises Web Mimms's heroic sacrifice, calling him a hero.
Offers help to Dr. Mimms, saying 'If there's anything we can do for you, Dr. Mimms. We want to help.'
Says he will fight anyone to keep his farm and protect his home, showing determination but potential stubbornness.
Pauses to emotionally watch Zee enter the house, showing a moment of silent concern and attachment before riding away.
Refuses to engage with Frank’s teasing and tells him off curtly.
Responds quickly and positively to a suggested story to protect himself and his family by saying 'That just might work.'
Stares thoughtfully at the door after leaving, showing emotional conflict and possibly hesitation.
Engages in banter with Frank, showing confidence and control in conversation.
Does not immediately object to Zee's dismissal of his story, indicating emotional restraint or strategic patience.
Nods approval of Ma showing kindness to Comanche Tom, acknowledging his acceptance despite racial differences.
Responds to Ma’s question about killing Yankees with quiet honesty.
Shares a lighthearted, joking exchange with Frank about Ma talking to Jesus.
Engages in friendly teasing and laughter with Cole and Frank while working together.
Thanks Cole for his help with the farm work.
Makes a crude joke about Sadie having a moustache, teasing Cole.
Shows respect and affection by wanting to use a Shakespeare quote to flatter Zerelda.
Responds ironically to Rollin Parker's greeting as 'Easterners,' indicating a friendly but teasing nature toward outsiders.
Acknowledges Frank's compliment about being 'terrifying' with guns with a non-regretful 'Yeah,' showing acceptance but no clear sign of warmth or friendliness.
Engages Parker with a sarcastic comment about the railroad president going 'underwater,' demonstrating wit but also a dismissive tone.
Draws and cocks two Colts quickly in defense of the family confronting the land sales agent and Pinkerton.
Shrugs off question about where he got guns, showing nonchalant reassurance.
Expresses empathy or mild frustration with 'Somebody's in a vengeful smiting mood today.'
Comments on reading and knowledge positively: 'Damn. All that reading paid off.'
Draws and cocks two Colts quickly and confidently when threatened.
Shrugs off question about where he got guns, showing calmness and control.
Acknowledges value of reading and research ('Damn. All that reading paid off.') indicating intelligence and appreciation of knowledge.
Notices Zee's comforting hand on his shoulder, acknowledges without discomfort or dismissal.
Sighs and calmly asks how many detectives Cole killed after the attack.
Tells the crowd to go home and swear they don't know about tomorrow's events, protecting them from involvement.
Softly reassures Doc Mimms that no more Liberty boys will be hanged, showing concern for others' safety.
Refuses Jim Younger's request to join because he's too young, showing protective judgment.
Tells Zee to go home despite Zee's insistence on gathering info, prioritizing group over individual curiosity.
Smiles while facing overwhelming odds in a dangerous situation.
Leaps from horse to slam into the Hangman and rescue a condemned man from execution.
Appears masked on horseback amidst a stampede of cattle, leaps onto the Hangman to stop the execution, and helps rescue captured comrades.
Cuts the rope on Cole’s wrists to free him from bindings.
Exchanges a look with Cole showing mutual trust and coordination during the escape.
Leaps on a horse and escapes with Cole after freeing him.
Allows Zee to protect him by hiding under the quilt and remains calm despite danger.
Smiles gently in his sleep, showing vulnerability and friendliness.
Accepts support from Zee and shares a warm, teasing conversation with her, showing affection and mutual care.
Modestly downplays his heroic act and acknowledges others' risks, showing sincerity and humility.
Returns home gingerly after being bedridden for two weeks, shows willingness to recover and resume activity.
Acknowledges others' contributions in risky actions, not taking all credit for rescuing Cole.
Engages in warm, good-natured banter with Zee, demonstrating social confidence and emotional intelligence.
Unusually awkwardly asks Doc Mimms if he could come by and take Zee out nearby with other people around.
Turns to glare slowly at Frank after Frank jokes about chaperoning.
Swings Zee into a group of dancers, joining in the fun smoothly and inclusively.
Shares a childhood fantasy with Zee and jokes playfully about being a river pirate.
Engages in sincere and playful conversation showing openness about future hopes and personal thoughts.
Recites Shakespeare poetry awkwardly but with genuine intent when talking to Zee, then confidently initiates a kiss.
Responds quickly and decisively when the barn is set on fire and promptly rides off with Frank after being informed of the Pinkerton railroad attack.
Rejects immediate violent revenge; advocates strategic harassment targeting supply lines to minimize direct casualties.
Supports Cole's idea to involve a girl at the bank to gather intelligence, showing trust and inclusion.
Acknowledges Zee's sorrow and quietly informs her about having to leave, without displaying overt emotion or comfort.
Rejects reckless vengeance, advocates strategic harassment of enemy supply lines instead of direct confrontation.
Effectively rallies and plans with his gang, approves and supports Cole's intelligence gathering plan.
Calmly and confidently takes initiative by arming himself preparing for action.
Gently kisses Zee before leaving despite her visible anger and heartbreak.
Refuses to answer Zee's question about whose justice he serves, implying a harsh personal code.
Threatens to make people 'cry in their sleep' and 'bring them to ashes' as part of his revenge.
Interrupts a bank scene by claiming the railroad payroll was stolen, then draws guns threateningly.
Engages in a staredown with the bank manager, showing confidence and command during the robbery.
Half covers his eyes and turns his head away during a violent threat, indicating some discomfort or hesitation.
Raises a hand to stop the gang from shooting the Sherriff, offering him to choose the smart way or the stupid way, showing restraint.
Says, 'Just 'cause we're robbing a bank, no reason not to be civil about it.'
Suggests taking some of the stolen money to give to neighbors who are hurting.
Calms the group by reminding that the money isn't truly theirs to keep.
Discusses leadership and planning to save Cole from execution, showing loyalty.
Reads the newspaper about the gang's bank robbery, acknowledges the injuries caused but takes pride in their notoriety.
Plans to 'set the record straight' themselves next time, showing leadership and concern for the gang’s reputation.
Leads a successful raid involving exchange of fire with Pinkerton Guards, killing several and robbing the payroll office, demonstrating tactical skill and effective planning.
Has his horse trample Pinkerton, injuring him, showing aggressive, perhaps reckless behavior with potential consequences.
A well-written newspaper article is reportedly authored by Jesse James himself, showing boldness and media savvy to shape public perception.
The gang successfully robs a railroad depot despite being outnumbered by Pinkerton detectives, indicating skill and daring.
Doc Mimms expresses confidence that Jesse and Cole 'know what they're doing' and 'won't press their luck', implying prudent judgement and avoid reckless behavior.
Warns the train engineer with clear signs about dynamite ahead, preventing a disaster.
Grins at the engineer and fireman after nearly causing a deadly accident with TNT barrels.
Sets up a complex warning system with signs and a fake TNT wagon to stop a train without causing harm.
Successfully stops the train just in time, demonstrating precise timing and control.
Enters the bank dressed in suits despite being publicly wanted, showing boldness and confidence in disguise.
Reacting calmly and with a grin after the engineer nearly crashes, indicating confident control over the situation.
Hands a bill to the teller and politely asks, 'Could you change this please?'
When accused of passing a counterfeit bill, calmly requests to examine the teller's real bills to compare, showing a composed and sincere demeanor.
Draws a weapon aggressively after the teller accuses him, indicating threat rather than friendly interaction.
Tears down his wanted poster and autographs it for a young boy.
Engages in friendly banter with cousins about the gang's name.
Tears down his wanted poster and autographs it for a young boy
Nods confidently with Cole while riding hard and checking their pursuers
Engages in a light-hearted discussion about gang naming, showing a willingness to listen and acknowledge others' points.
Leads the James Gang in a quick and successful bank robbery, escaping swiftly with full saddlebags.
Operates a gang that effectively evades law enforcement over a large territory for eight months, exploiting terrain and moving rapidly between jobs.
The gang's ability to walk openly as heroes in some towns suggests skillful management of public image and local support.
Drops a handful of twenty dollar gold pieces in church collection plate, showing confidence and generosity.
Writes a letter on fancy stationery, coached by Frank, indicating planning and thoughtful communication.
Manages the stick-up in the bank calmly, addresses the teller politely and de-escalates tension despite Bob's aggressive outburst.
Acknowledges Bob's jealousy about publicity with a sigh, showing awareness of group dynamics but perhaps limited direct leadership resolution.
Smoothly manages the situation with Bob Younger and the crowd during the robbery, keeping control and commanding respect.
Receives admiration and loyalty from his gang and associates, indicating effective leadership.
Acknowledges the dangers and nature of their outlaw life with frankness and confidence.
Expresses confidence and acceptance of his violent, outlaw lifestyle despite risks and consequences.
Shows emotional impulsiveness by hurling a whisky bottle against the wall in frustration.
Attempts to de-escalate tension with Frank by expressing love and preventing physical confrontation.
Acknowledges the costs of their actions reluctantly but does not show clear strategic reconsideration.
Listens patiently to Jim, keeps his promise not to tell anyone Jim's secret.
Responds tersely or indifferently to Jim's struggles (e.g., 'You do that.' when Jim throws up).
Remains silent and composed after Jim's awkward behavior, then thoughtfully beckons the bartender, showing social awareness and calm control.
Engages Jim in conversation asking personal questions (about girls), demonstrating social perceptiveness and leadership in the group.
Responds with minimal verbal communication (e.g., 'I guess so', 'I think so'), indicating reserved or cautious interaction rather than overreaction or impulsiveness.
Does not intervene or correct Jim's embarrassment or lack of sophistication in social situations, potentially missing an opportunity to guide or protect his younger brother.
Glares at Cole Younger and spits sarcastically after Cole criticizes him
Refuses to back down and escalates conflict to physical fight and then a gun duel with Cole Younger
Maintains a dominant presence in the gang, confronts Cole Younger confidently, and wins a street fight with a roundhouse punch.
Dismisses Cole's ideas outright without engaging in constructive discussion, escalating conflict within the gang.
Provokes and engages in escalating violence within the gang, risking division and instability.
Engages in careful discussion about the planned robbery, expressing skepticism about the job's risk ('Still smells fishy').
Defers command to Cole Younger's leadership but maintains influence ('Fine. We hit this bank').
Physically shows exhaustion, sagging against the window after the planning, which may indicate strain or stress.
Draws six guns and participates actively and decisively in the bank raid with Frank and Cole.

Kicks a stool at an armed assailant, dives and rolls across a desk while firing accurately, kills multiple attackers, uses agile and confusing movement to disorient enemies, and takes cover effectively during a surprise attack.
Moves surviving gang members into the vault to protect them from gunfire.
Warns others to get inside before exposing himself to danger.
Takes daring action by crashing through a window to retrieve dynamite for the gang's defense.
Recognizes the situation as a trap promptly and moves the gang into the bank vault for shelter.
Assesses the pinned situation and comes up with a daring plan, using dynamite to try to escape.
Crashes through a window twice in quick succession to retrieve dynamite, showing confident physical skill and courage under fire.
Uses dynamite to cause explosions and fire to attack Pinkerton forces, showing disregard for property and causing widespread destruction.
Leads the gang to escape quickly after the bank attack, urging no delay.
Supports and helps carry wounded Jim Younger after he is shot during the escape.
Supports injured Jim and insists on sending for a doctor despite the long ride.
Passes Jim some whisky even though he says he's too young, making an exception for him.
Comforts Jim by promising to explain things to Lyla when Jim is resting, showing concern for his friend’s peace of mind.
Expresses deep grief and anguish over Jim’s death, indicating sincere emotional investment in his comrades.
Uses sarcasm in response to Frank’s attempt to console, calling him a ‘piss-poor liar’ despite acknowledging Frank as smart.
Tells the gang he is out after a comrade is killed, expressing concern over continued violence and danger.
Refuses to force others to follow him, stating they can choose their own path.
Attempts to shake hands with Cole, but guilt and rage make it impossible; smiles sadly and walks away.
Visits Zee secretly despite dangers, showing sincerity and longing.
Shares openly with Zee about his marriage intentions and his complex feelings.
Decides to quit the gang after a fatal incident, recognizing the dangers and refusing to continue a likely doomed path.
Walks away from Cole after an emotionally charged moment, showing emotional control and clear decision-making.
Returns to see Zee despite the presence of bounty hunters and lawmen, demonstrating confidence and prioritizing personal matters.
Makes a serious and surprising announcement about getting married, showing conviction and decisiveness.
Gives a contradictory compliment on the woman he is marrying (smart but with 'the biggest buck teeth'), possibly showing a lapse in social sensitivity.
Drops to one knee and proposes to Zee, expressing a desire to quit outlaw ways and live honestly with her.
Expresses affection openly to Zee during carriage ride; chooses a peaceful, new life for them.
Jokingly responds to religion question with tolerant answer: 'Whichever one has God in it, that'll do fine.'
Fills out marriage license honestly using his real name despite potential danger; insists on legal legitimacy.
Quits outlaw ways and takes steps to start a new life by proposing marriage and arranging it quickly and confidently.
Directs the driver decisively with a change of plans, showing clear leadership and confidence.
Deals with the pastor openly and presents payment confidently, showing social intelligence and pragmatism.
Expresses desire to start a new life and wants the marriage to be legal, showing sincerity and respect for the law and the Pastor.
Generously pays the Pastor to repair the church roof and participates in a communion drink, indicating respect, friendliness, and goodwill toward the community.
Having a relaxed picnic with Zee, engaging playfully with her reading about his reputation.
Focuses on leisure and affection with Zee rather than criminal activities in this moment.
Maintains a reputation that causes people to 'snap to' and shows awareness of his gang's image.
Engages casually and confidently with Zee, showing composure and charm.
Successfully charms others, playful and confident with Zee, momentarily evades direct confrontation by heading for the shore despite imminent arrest.
Fails to notice or respond effectively to the presence of fifty armed Pinkerton detectives on the beach, allowing himself to be arrested.
Maintains physical discipline by doing push-ups despite being chained and imprisoned.
Displays a dry sense of humor telling Pinkerton he likes the 'presidential suite' sarcastically.
Performs push-ups easily despite being chained, showing physical fitness and mental toughness.
Engages in verbal banter with Pinkerton confidently, not intimidated by his captor.
Clearly understands and anticipates legal and tactical disadvantages, demonstrating situational awareness and strategic thinking.
Successfully identified an ambush by analyzing subtle cues about cattle brands and troop placements, showing intelligence and tactical skill.
Recalls a near-miss shooting and recognizes the impact on his team morale, indicating good battlefield awareness.

Considers a decisive action ('Should have just killed Thaddeus Rains'), implying some regret over missed opportunities, which reflects reflection but also a limitation in taking immediate strong action.
Acknowledges Parker and confronts him about killing his Ma.
Winks and taunts Rains about making him think twice about burning homes.
Shares a moment of casual conversation and smoking with Pinkerton, showing familiarity despite hostility.
Spots the club car several cars away despite being guarded and chained, indicating alertness and situational awareness.
Threatens Rains confidently despite being a prisoner and chained among many guards, showing mental toughness and confidence.
Attempts to intimidate his captors with his words, demonstrating psychological confidence even when physically restrained.
Despite being heavily guarded and chained with arms suspended, does not show signs of panic or defeat, implying emotional control and resilience.
Confidently provokes and verbally taunts Burly Detective despite potential danger.
Maintains composure and even grins while injured after being backhanded.
Faces down a gun pointed at his face with calm and a low, terrifying voice.
Kicks Burly Detective hard despite the threat of gunfire and dodges a shot skillfully.
Shows mercy by sparing Rains after threatening to shoot him, offers to buy his watch for a fair price.
Kills Parker during the gunfight.
Swings off his horse and greets Cole with a bear hug; expresses sincere mutual affection ('Missed you too, cousin'); clasps hands with Cole.
Rejects the idea that he feared capture after leaving the gang, showing loyalty and trust towards others ('the thought never crossed my mind').
Acknowledges and appreciates Zerelda's role in recruiting riders, showing respect and gratitude towards his wife.
Shares plans to retire with his wife and says goodbye sincerely to the gang, who respond sadly but respectfully.
Shows appreciation to Frank for providing a distraction ('I appreciate the distraction back there'), demonstrating gratitude and camaraderie.
Portrayed through Frank James' memories as a man who saved people from the railroad and was 'a real interestin' fella to have around.'
Acknowledged to have killed many men, showing a violent side.
Frank softly recalls Jesse and allows himself to 'soften a few of the edges up,' suggesting a tolerant, forgiving view of Jesse's character.
Is remembered by family as a complex man who saved people from the railroad but also killed many men; family members tell softened, nostalgic versions of his past.
